Description A: Thermal nociceptors are activated by extremes in temperature, typically greater than 45°C (115°F) or less than 5°C (41°F).
Description B: Thermal nociceptors are activated by mild changes in temperature, typically around 25°C (77°F) or higher.

Description A: Mechanical nociceptors are activated optimally by intense pressure applied to the skin.
Description B: Mechanical nociceptors are activated optimally by light pressure applied to the skin.

Description A: Most nociceptors are simply the free nerve endings of primary sensory neurons.
Description B: Most nociceptors are specialized structures with complex endings.

Description A: Polymodal nociceptors can be activated by high-intensity mechanical, chemical, or thermal stimuli.
Description B: Polymodal nociceptors are only activated by low-intensity thermal stimuli.

Description A: Myelinated Aδ axons conduct action potentials at speeds of 5 to 30 m/s.
Description B: Myelinated Aδ axons conduct action potentials at speeds less than 1.0 m/s.

Description A: Unmyelinated C-fiber axons conduct action potentials at speeds less than 1.0 m/s.
Description B: Unmyelinated C-fiber axons conduct action potentials at speeds of 5 to 30 m/s.

Description A: There are three main classes of nociceptors—thermal, mechanical, and polymodal.
Description B: There are two main classes of nociceptors—thermal and mechanical.

Description A: The perception of pain arises from and can be controlled by cortical mechanisms.
Description B: The perception of pain is a simple reflex that cannot be modulated by cortical mechanisms.

Description A: First and second pain are carried by A delta and C fibers, respectively.
Description B: First and second pain are carried by A beta and C fibers, respectively.

Description A: Noxious insults activate thermal, mechanical, and polymodal nociceptors.
Description B: Noxious insults activate only thermal nociceptors.

Description A: Pain's highly individual and subjective nature makes it difficult to define objectively and to treat clinically.
Description B: Pain's objective nature makes it easy to define and treat clinically.

Description A: Electrical stimulation of the brain produces analgesia.
Description B: Electrical stimulation of the brain produces increased pain perception.

Description A: Opioid peptides contribute to endogenous pain control.
Description B: Opioid peptides have no role in pain control.

Description A: Morphine controls pain by activating opioid receptors.
Description B: Morphine controls pain by deactivating opioid receptors.

Description A: Acute, persistent, or extreme cases of chronic pain can be experienced.
Description B: Only acute pain can be experienced; persistent or chronic pain does not exist.

Description A: The hippocampus is associated with multiple cognitive functions and behaviors.
Description B: The hippocampus is associated with a single cognitive function.

Description A: fMRI provides an opportunity to study the function of the human brain in both health and disease.
Description B: fMRI provides an opportunity to alter the function of the human brain in both health and disease.

Description A: fMRI does not support inferences about whether a brain region is necessary for a behavior.
Description B: fMRI supports inferences about whether a brain region is necessary for a behavior.

Description A: Functional brain imaging methods in cognitive neuroscience seek to record activity associated with mental processes.
Description B: Functional brain imaging methods in cognitive neuroscience seek to manipulate activity associated with mental processes.

Description A: fMRI is based on the physics of magnetic resonance and the biology of neurovascular coupling.
Description B: fMRI is based on the chemistry of nuclear resonance and the biology of cell communication.

Description A: Human brain imaging has led to fundamental insights about neural mechanisms across many domains.
Description B: Human brain imaging has led to changes in neural mechanisms across many domains.

Description A: These applications of fMRI raise ethical and privacy concerns.
Description B: These applications of fMRI resolve ethical and privacy concerns.

Description A: The discovery of MRI came from physics and chemistry.
Description B: The discovery of MRI came from biology and geology.

Description A: fMRI evidence is generally inadmissible in court.
Description B: fMRI evidence is generally admissible in court.

Description A: The BOLD response helps measure neuronal activity during cognitive tasks.
Description B: The BOLD response helps measure vacuum activity during cognitive tasks.

Description A: Some patients in a vegetative state exhibit brain activity reflecting mental processing.
Description B: All patients in a vegetative state lack any brain activity reflecting mental processing.

Description A: fMRI technology is undergoing continual development to improve spatial resolution.
Description B: fMRI technology has reached its peak development in spatial resolution.

Description A: Forward inferences in fMRI studies link brain activity to manipulated mental processes.
Description B: Backward inferences in fMRI studies confirm brain activity unrelated to tasks.

Description A: Blood flow can increase in the visual cortex without an increase in neuronal activity if a visual cue is expected but not presented.
Description B: Blood flow cannot increase in the visual cortex without an increase in neuronal activity regardless of visual cue expectations.

Description A: The history of fMRI shows scientific discoveries in one field can lead to breakthroughs in another.
Description B: The history of fMRI shows scientific discoveries are confined to their original field.
